titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, National Affairs Division, Office Files of George Esser
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, National Affairs Division, Office Files of George Esser FA1553

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-21 19:31:12 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, National Affairs Division, Office Files of George Esser

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains the office files of Ford Foundation Program Advisor George Esser. Esser served as Program Advisor for the South in the Foundation's National Affairs Division between the late 1960s and early 1970s. The collection is comprised of two types of records housed within two separate series. The first series contains Esser's subject files, while the second contains his correspondence files.

Esser's subject files were created to document his work with the different community, philanthropic, academic, and state and local government organizations he advised in the southern states of America. They generally regard specific proposals, projects, and activities. His correspondence files were created to document his communications with individuals associated with those different types of organizations over two different time spans: 1970-1972 and 1968-1970. The correspondence they contain is arranged alphabetically by the names of Esser's correspondents.

In addition to correspondence, material formats such as memos, reports, proposals, meeting agendas and minutes, brochures, publications, and newspaper clippings are prevalent throughout the collection. Records concern subjects like housing, rural and urban economic development, poverty, racial discrimination, African American voting rights and political participation, and public policy education. The support provided by Program Assistant Lucy Waktins and Program Officer Bryant George to Esser's activities is documented throughout the collection.

The collection is comprised of more than one transfer of George Esser office files made to the RAC. Records from a 2018 Ford Foundation records, Special Collections Accession (2018:017) were added to the later 2019 Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, George Esser Accession (2019:076) in order to complete the set of correspondence files contained in Series 2.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas. During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Subject files in Series 1 originate entirely from the 2019:076 Accession of George Esser office files, and correspondence files in Series 2 originate from both the 2019:076 Accession and the 2018:017, Ford Foundation records, Special Collections Accession. Material in the Correspondence files series is organized alphabetically by the names of the correspondents. This alphabetical system of arrangement revealed an obvious point where the files from 2018:017 continued the run of correspondence files contained in 2019:076. The 2018:017 materials were therefore added to where the materials from 2019:076 ended.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George H. Esser, Jr. (1921-2006) was a civil rights advocate and foundation program officer. Between the late 1960s and early 1970s, he served as Program Advisor for the South within the Ford Foundation's National Affairs Division. During his time at the Foundation, he advised various community, philanthropic, academic, and state and local government organizations working in and aiding the South. He chiefly supported projects and initiatives related to housing, rural and urban economic development, African American voting rights and political participation, and public policy education.

Esser earned a law degree from Harvard University. Prior to joining the Ford Foundation, he served as Director of the North Carolina Fund, an anti-poverty program supported by the Ford Foundation. After he left the Ford Foundation in 1972, he became Executive Director of the Southern Regional Council.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011.

This material was transferred to the RAC in two different set of records in 2018 and 2019. One box of material was ingested by the RAC in 2018 as part of Accession 2018:017, Ford Foundation records, Special Collections. The rest of the material was ingested by the RAC in 2019 as Accession 2019:076, Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, George Esser. Accessions continue as necessary.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection materials originated from two different sets of records transferred to the Rockefeller Archive Center: Accession 2018:017 Ford Foundation records, Special Collections and Accession 2019:076 Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, George Esser. Analysis of the records' content revealed that the documents were all the office files of George Esser, and the discovery of an alphabetical arrangement scheme carrying over from the 2018:017 Accession to some of the files in the 2019:076 Accession further proved the common origin of the documents. It was therefore decided to process the records from the two accessions into a single collection in respect of the arrangement scheme binding the files together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of the subject files George Esser created during his time as the Ford Foundation's Program Advisor for the South. Esser's subject files document his work with different community organizations, social advocacy groups, foundations, universities, research institutions, and state and local government organizations working in and aiding the southern states of America. They include material formats like correspondence, memos, reports, proposals, meeting agendas and minutes, brochures, publications, and newspaper clippings. One file also contains a few photographs.

Esser advised organizations like the Delta Foundation which sought to support rural economic development, different state chapters of the Voter Education Project (VEP) which each sought to protect African Americans voting rights and promote voter education, the American Society for Public Administration (ASPA) which sought to strengthen the public administration community through education and training, and, in addition to many others, the University of Miami, Coral Gables which received a grant from the Ford Foundation for research and action programs on urban problems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs in the file are of the Public Affairs Seminar on black officials at Southern University in Baton Rouge, Louisiana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of the correspondence files George Esser created during his time as the Ford Foundation's Program Advisor for the South. Correspondence in the files is organized alphabetically by the names of Esser's correspondents. There are two alphabetical runs of files within the series. The first run contains correspondence that originates from the years 1970 to 1972, while the second run contains correspondence that originates from the years 1968 to 1970. No attempts were made during the processing of the collection to chronologically arrange the alphabetical correspondence file runs.

Correspondence in the series documents George Esser's communications with individuals associated with community organizations, social advocacy groups, foundations, universities, research institutions, and state and local governments working in and aiding the southern states of America. There is also some correspondence between Esser and other Ford Foundation staff members. Esser's correspondence concerns project proposals, invitations and follow up conversations to meetings, workshops and conferences, and a paper Esser was preparing with Bryant George about the Ford Foundation's strategy for the South.

Files in the series originate from two different transfers of George Esser office files made to the RAC. The two groups of records were organized into the same series in order to restore the alphabetical arrangement of the correspondence files.
